div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. ] ALEXANDRIA, MONDAY, JULY 1, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.

body.div:
RUSSIAN, DISORDERS. MUTINY SPREADING "ODESSA BOMBARDED. THE POTEMKIN SURRENDERS RUSSIAN, DISORDERS. ■r —•— MUTINY SPEEADING ■ODESSA BOMBARDED. THE POTEMKIN SURRENDERS Sevastopol, June 30.) Four battleships, one cruiser and several torpedo boats left here yesterday evening under the command of A b .iral Kruger/ with orders to sink the “Potemkin” if she refuses to sur- render, and then assist in restoring order in town.; (Reuter.) Odessa, June 30. The "Potemkin” began to bombard the town at 11.30 yesterday evening. The transport "Vecha” has joined the muti- neers. The central railway station has been burnt. The funeral of the sailor who was shot tor presenting the petition lor better food, was a great popular demonstration. There was do disorder. Neither police nor troops were on the route. The burnt shipe include the “Saratow” of the Volunteer Fleet. (Reuter.) Libau, June 30. The seamen here have mutinied and wrecked the barracks. 'The Cossacks and artillery have been called out and fighting has ensued, but there are no details. (Reuter.) (jfDESSA, June 30. Nii e vessels have been burned, but it is believed that none of them were British. Machine guns were used to clear the streets. Two more regiments have arrived. (Reuter.) St. Petersburg, June 30. It is reported that a mutiny has broken out at Cronstadt, and that the sailors have stoned a number of officers. The troops at Peterhof, where the Tsar is, have been reinforced. (R.) Washington, June 30. The American Consul at Odessa telegraphs that the fleet arrived at noon, and that the "Potemkin” surrendered without firing a shot. (Reuter.) Odessa, June 30. % Martial law has been proclaimed. The funeral of the sailor, whose death was the canse of the mutiny, took place yesterday. The police did not make an appearance. Owing to the arrest of the sailors, the "Potemkin” bombarded the town. The sailors were released. (Harm.) THE “PERESVIET” REFLOATED. Port Arthur, June 30. The battleship “Peresviet” has been refloat ed here. (Reuter) FRANCE AND GERMANY. EARLY SETTLEMENT EXPECTED. Paris, June 30. It is announced that M. Rouvier will hand a note to Prince Radoliu to-day accepting the conference, regarding Morocco. (Reuter.; Paris, June 30. It is expected that the Franco-German inci- dent will be settled next week. (Hava*.) EGYPT’S JUDICIAL REFORM. Paris, June 30. The Chamber of Deputies has agreed to the prolongation of the judicial reform in Egypt. (Harm!) EAST FINSBURY ELECTION. LOCAL AND GENERAL. The Plague.- a fatal case at Ashmoun. -Yesterday’s bulletin records Port Said and another at
A Foundling..—A lining new-born r&ild was found yesterday in the Haret el Balkatria, and was sent to the hospital. j Public Instruction.—Mr. Dunlop will seleot 25 gentlemen whilst he is in England to add to the staff of Government school instructors. Course o^ the Nile.- 6,350 has been opened for the course of the Nile Cataracts. -A credit of L.E. an examination of near the Upper Crown Casino.—A variety company makes its debut this evening^ at the new theatre which has been built at the Crown Casino, Ibrahimieb. Stray and Ownerless Dogs found in the Effiekieh district of Cairo during the night of Monday and at daylight on Tuesday will be poisoned by the police. French Gomedy.— TheGonnet Levy-French comedy company arrived at Alexandria this morning and opens this evening at? the Eden Theatre with the 3-aet comedy Alnie Mongodin. Suez Canal.— 9 vessels passed through the Canal on the 28th ulto., 4 of which were British, 2 German, 1 Dutch, 2 Turkish. The day’s receipts were fra. 207,947.32, making the total from 1st June frs. 7,714,139.54. SPEECH BY LOBD CROMER. THE CONDITIONS OF EGYPT'S PROGRESS. ^Special Cable to the Gazette. ) / \ __________________ London, Jnne 30. The Earl of Cromer has jecei^Sft the honorary freedom of the Skinners’ Company. His lord- ship, in replying to. the toast of his health, declared that the ADglo French Agreemeut had been of unmixed benefit to all whb had to deal with the local affairs of Egypt and wore now relieved from the constant friction and annoyance that haul marked the past. The story circulated in the Press to the effect that representations had been made to H.H. the Khedive as to the presence of British troops in Egypt was purely mythical. Four conditions were necessary to secure the uniform progress of Egypt : first, no hurry; second, that Egyptian affairs should be kept outside the domain of British party politios ; third, that the utmost care should be taken not to force Western ideas and exotic institutions upon the Egyptian people before the country was ripe for their assimilation; fourth, that Egypt should continue in the future as in the past to be governed in the interests of the Egyptians themselves. V _______ • • (Reuter’s Telegram) London, Jnne 30. The Earl of Cromer, speaking at the banquet of the Skinners’ Company, dwelt upon the benefit to Egypt caused by the Anglo-French entente, and the valuable co-operation of the Egyptian Government. His relations with the , Ihedive were most satisfactory. Fatal Accident. — An Italian named Gae- tano Flatino, aged 65 years, was run down by a cab in the Attarin quarter yesterday. His skull was fractured and he expired within a few minutes after being conveyed to the french Hospital. "Under the Mosquito.Net.”—The notes under this title which /e usually publish in our Saturday’s issue will not appear during the next few weeks. The concluding portion of the article entitled "The Principles of Heredity" is also similarly postponed. At- Thursday’s meeting of the Legislative Council, Ibrahim Effendi Abd el Al, the new Fayoum delegate, was presented to the mem- bers, and the proposal for the formation of an Armenian Catholic community discussed. It was • finally decided to have these proposals printed and distributed among the members of the Council The Coined meets again on August 1. PUBLIC WORKS.
Coal Imports. — From 1st January to 29th June, 458,233 tons of coal were imported into Egypt Wales sent 260,729 tons, Newcastle 87,864, Scotland 65,132, Yorkshire 26,876 and other places 17,632 tons.During the same period of last year the imports amounted to 482,943 tons. Shepheard’s Buildings.—A short while ago we informed the public that the shops which form part of the buildings of Shepheard’s Hotel were to be pulled down and larger ones erected in their place. The work ot destruction ias already been commenced and four of the shops are being rapidly demolished. Sudan Mines.—Application has been made to the committee of the London Stock Exchange to appoint a special settling day in Sudan Mines, Limited—Further issue of 400 shares of £1 each, 2s 6d paid (Nos. 1 to 200 and 401 to 600); and 3,896 shares of £1 each, fully paid (Nos. 7,605 to 11,500). LIBERAL GAIN. London, June 30. Mr. Baker, Liberal, 2,320, Mr. Cohen, Con- servative, 1,552; in succession to Mr. Richards, deceased. This is a Liberal gaiD. (Reuter.) J HOME CRICKET London, June 30. Kent beat Yorkshire by six wickets. (R.\ -— ERAMD HOTEL BONNARD, ALBXANDaii. •».’ PER DAY, WINE INCLUDED' ICKI It T Anglo-American Nile Steamer Sr .HOTEL COMPANY. Among various credits that have been opened by the Ministry of Finance we note the sum of LE. 11,000 for the neoeesary repairs to the Tewfikieh School, LE. 4,750 I or the construction of new agricultural roads in Ghizeh Frovinoe, L.E. 1,500 for repairs to the Alexandria Mixed Court of Appeal, L.EL 950 for the improvement of the harbour lights at the entrance to the port of Alexandria, and smaller credits for the purchase of the necessary material for the sinking of artesian wells in the mining districts, for the pappose of pomps,and for the purchase of dog muzz'es rendered necessary by the new law relating to rabies. Alhambra Theatre.—The excellent Italian operetta company which is holding the boards of this playhouse continues to attract large audiences. This evening, the company will stage Suppl’s popular operetta Donna Juanita. To-morrow alternoon La Gran Via will be given with the first and second acts of I Grandtieri. . > ______ Seizure of Hashish.—On Wednesday and Thursday last the Coastguards made seizures of no less than 500 and 200 okes of hashish on the small islands off A game. It had been de- posited on the islands by the smugglers while awaiting an opportunity to pass it to the shore, which is so well guarded that it is now a matter of extreme difficulty to land hashish. Before the transfer of the above large quantities could be managed the Coast- guards got wind of its concealment and seized it. The Kanaan Affair.— The Native Par- quet of the Minet-el-Bassal Kiam has presented its report to the Gouvemorat on the Kanaan affair. We are glad to hear that an enquiry has been opened on the subject, and hope that it will be possible to disoover who was respon- sible for the extraordinary mistake made by some one in the t ative Hospital who ordered the burial of the corpse without a proper inquest, and noted the discovery of the body of a Sudanese 1 Why not a Japanese or an Eskimo 1 "King’s English.”—A very interesting ar- ticle appeared a short time ago, showing the great differences in the language, add espe- cially of pronunciation, in different parts ol England, and a witty allusion was also mad? to. '“American English.” It admitted, however, that many modem Americanisms were in use in tCe time of Shakespeare, but the universal opinion- is that there is only one English worthy 'of the nine, whioh is “King’s English,” and special care is taken to keep only to tlt^JpnnAhronghout all the Berlitz Schools, p. 2rt] . LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL. ^(From our owit Correspondent.) 1 Sfiez, Friday. As I advised yon this morning by wire, I proceeded on board the Russian cruiser “Dnieper” (ex “St. Petersburg”) In order to interview the crew of the sunken British steamer “St. Kilda,” but the officer on duty absolutely refused tc allow me to see any of the British offioers, saying that it was strictly forbidden. He added at the same time that they would probably oe landed at Fort Said. I understand, however, that the S.S. “St. lilda” left Hongkong for Yokohama on the 4th June, with a ctpgo of rioe, cotton, and Bmp, and wh« 40 miles oat she met the laSStaff cruiser "Dnieper,” which signalled to ler to stop. A "prize crew was subsequently put on board, and next- day, when the orew iad*been removed, the oruiser sank the “St. lilda” after firing ten shots. All the personal effeots belonging to the orew were lost. 41 of the Chinese crew belonging to the “St Kilda” were transferred to th&putoh steamer “Flores” and landed at Singapore, while the British officers were retained and brought here. It is remarkable that' the “Dnieper,’’ in spite of the long voyage and the heavy seas she en- countered, has the appearance of having been recently drydocked. She is heavily armed with arge and small machine guns, and fitted with wireless apparatus. She is also flying the naval flag. J At about 9.30 a.m. to-day the Russian com- mander paid an official call on the commander of the British battleship "Canopus,” whioh was duly returned. The same offioial calls were exchanged later on between the battleship “Goliath,” whi6h arrived at 10.30 a.m., and the “Dnieper.” The battleship “Goliath” was reported by the “Canopus” as approaching Suez at 7 a.m., >eing in wireless communication with her. Finally the battleship “Canopns” entered the Canal at i 1.15 this morning. * The "Goliath” left at 1.40 this afternoon, and the “Dnieper” at 1.55 for Port Said, where, !, understand, she will take in abont 300 tons of ooal, not having taken anything at this port. DANGEROUS GAMINS. We wish to call the attention of the an tho- rites to the dangerous use of catapults in the streets by European and Arab boys. These gapiins appear to be supplied with up-to-date weapons, and samples of their ammunition which we have seen look most formidable, small bolt heads and chopped iron bars being the pattern most in favour. Every evening parties of boys may be seen in the quieter streets, especially in the Moharrem Bay quarter, shooting at the small birds whioh settle on the tamarisks planted'by the road. We imagine' that the use of catapults on the public roads is forbidden, and there can be nodonbt about the i’legality of their use when missiles are fired into gardens with disastrous consequences to windows and grave risk to the eyesight of those who happen to be in the line of fire. Even the Mohamed Aly-square is rendered unsafe : the windows of St Mark’s Church have repeatedly been broken by stones and lamps of iron. Mr. Casimatis, of the Anglo- Egyptian Bank, wtifr is also in charge of part of the business administration of the church, has made an interesting collection of ammuni- tion fired into the windows and has oaptured two of the oplprits, whom he handed over to the police—without any obvious result. This morning the bowab of the church^w^s struck on the left side of the face by a stone from a ! catapult which infiioted a very nasty wound. Had the missile struck the unfortunate man an inch higher he would probably have lost the sight o^ one eye. We hope that the autho- rities will take steps to render the repetition 1 ot the offence highly dangerous tothe offenders. SAN STEFANO CASINO. I The following is the programme . of the Wagner oonoert to be given to-morrow, com- mencing at 10.30 a.m. :— 1 Hal*ngungs Marsch. 5 Ouverture do Rienzi, 3 Proludo Lohengrin. 4 Entire dos dienx dana le Walhall do “l’or du Rhia.” 6 Ouverture doe Maitre»*Chantours. STEAMER MOVEMENTS. ------•----->; \ The Moss liner "Raineses” sailed yesterday afternoon for Liverpool, vift Malta, with pas- sengers, mails, and general cargo, including 4,247 bales cotton. KILDA.” JREW LANDING AT POET SAID INTERVIEW WITH CAPTAIN. HOW THE VESSEL WAS / SUNK. CAIRO TO PORT SAID. V (From our (From our own Correspondent.) > Port Said, Saturday. After considerable difficulties had been pnt in my way I at last obtained an interview with Captain Jones, of the S.S. “St. Kilda.” Captain Jones states that' the “St. Kilda” left Hongkong on June 2 last. The EuropBNl crew refused to proceed to Japan and were landed at Hongkong on Jane 3 and impri- soned. A Chinese crew was shipped and the "St. Kilda” sailed for Yokohama on the same day. 'On June 4 the Russian erniper “Dnieper” stopped and.captured the “St. Kilda,” putting a prize orew on board. The ships proceeded at a speed of nine knots in oompany into deep water and at 6 a.m. on the 5th June an un- successful attempt was made to sink the “St. Kilda” by means of dynamite, after the crew had been taken off. The Russians then opened fire with their quick-firers and sank the captured vessel with 16 4.7 inch projectiles at 10 a.m. The “St.-Kilda” was bound from Rangoon to Yokohama with a cargo of rice, cotton, and sugar. The “Dnieper” had been warned of her departure by Russian agents at Hong- Jcong. After the vessel had been sank the Chinese crew were put on board the S.S. “Flores,” bound for Singapore. The prisoners, who were thirteen in number, were well treated on the “Dnieper,” being each allowed a cabin and having perfect freedom of movement abont the decks. The commander of the “Dnieper”' refused to receive the visit of the captain of H.M.S. •’Lancaster” this morning. The Russian cruiser carries eight 4.7q.f. -guns and 27 pieces of smaller calibre ; she is bound for Libau and the prisoners have received orders to disembark at Port Said to-night. . MENZALEH CANAL AND NAVIGATION CO. This new company, founded last year, hopes to inaugurate tk6 Port Said to Matarieh branch of its service across Lake Menzaleh about the middle, of October. The Matarieh to Damletta seotion will also be completed soon after, dredging operations being now hastened for that purpose. The distance between the former two places is some 28 kilometres, and the same distance separatee; Damietta from Matarieh, where the lake service works in oonneotion with the passenger trains of the Compagnie des Chemins de for de la Basse Egygte to Mansourah and at the latter town in coincidence with those of the Sta’e Railways. c In Ootober therefore there will be a through service between Cairo and Port Said by rail- way and passenger steamer. For the latter traffic there are two stem-wheelers for passen* gers besides two tugs and six lighters for the freight traffic. All these were constraoted in England, brought out in sections, and put together at Karputi, near Port Sail, by the Anglo-American Nile Steamer Co., who have entered into a contract to work the lines of the Menzaleh Canal and Navigation Company for two years from the date of inauguration. The steamers have good aooommodation each for a certain number of first and second class passengers, besides 15^> of the third class. GERMANY AND TURKEY VERSUS ENGLAND IN THE NEAR EAST. BY W. M. FAYOUM LIGHT RAILWAY CO. was A correspondent writes:—Apropos of ao* oidenti on this railway, they are of almost daily occurrence now. On Friday last the Nesleh engine broke down as it was about to leave for Fayoum ; another engine was sent, but never reached its destination, and as no other was available passengers and train had neoessarily to wait ontiKohe of the other branch trains arrived at Fayenm, when -tiiat engine was sent and succeeded in returning home with its unfortunate com- panions “hours late.” The Shawashna train on the same day was never seen at Fayoum. A few days ago a funeral party ordered a "special” for 3 p.m. for Daire el Azab^j they arrived and had to sit in the train in the broiling afternoon sun until 5.30 p.m., when the engine from Lahoon took the train. No other was available. Last year the traffic receipts were published pretty regularly and always showed an increase. It would interest many to know' why they are now suppressed, as LE. 300 a month will not cover the decrease of receipts, and from what ean be gathered it is likely to be still more. It really is time the publio were better served and these directors were stopped Splaying at railways,” lor I am told that the native who is “running the show” at the moment, seising the moment'of chaos, actually threatened to resign “playing at puff puffs” unless he got more pay, and, in the face of this large and continued decrease of receipts, I hear he&4So have an increase of P.T. 200, so that the farce may continue— “Great Soot 1” — I. THE DANGER. (Continued.)——■ -The great line that runs tike an artery rom Constantinople to Konieh is to be carried on across the Taurus to branch off eastward to Ragdad and Koweit, southward to Aleppo and the Syrian system, is a military line par excellence. Its two branches will one day aid the German Empire to strike Britain in Asia and Afhoa. German diplomacy in Turkey has never ceased to keep the question of Egypt and Arabia alive and to suggest the possi- bility that a new Turkish army may day inflict on Britain the stroke of Exoatibur, - from whioh there is no recovery, cleaving in 1 twain the Empire without the slightest inter ference on the part of the fleet on which England’s hopes are centred. The Tnrko-German Staff aims at nothing less than an immediate advance on Egypt by an overwhelming Ottoman army, should war unhappily break out between Germany and Great Britain after the nomplt.iy, 0f the Ottoman strategic tines. The suooeai of the invasion would involve the suppression of the Mixed regime, the substitution of a dele- gate of the Saltan for our enlightened Sovereign and his British friends and adviiers, while the direoting power—which wonta not its position too strongly -» would be the German Empire. “ Delenda est Carthago ” and “ Unsere Zukonft tiegt am Wasaer" have an identical meaning in Germany. Her chief continental rival has been beaten down at Mukden and Tsusima by her adversary’s ally, and the Turkish. alliance. originally d— against Russia or England may now be direoted exclusively against the latter. Beware, England, or the day of yonr overthrow will see this ful- filment of the German dream and the wings of the eagles overshadowing half the world ! Neither in the Suez Canal, which a few merchantmen oould block to-morrow, nor in the straits of the Dardanelles, impregnably for tified by Von der Goltz and Brialmout against all the naviea of the world, can England maf her future foeA Her inflaenoe in Ifeypt^ her share in the - Sudan, her domination in the Aden Protectorate, Uganda, and East Africa are doomed, and these lost, will not the decay of British prestige lead to the loss of India from internal causes, unless— Yes, that will be the inevitable consequence of Britain’s Egyptian and Arabian policy, which has earned the frown of the Shadow of Allah, unless l er people, bringing into play the foresight and sagacity that , have made them great, have reoourse to the sole Remedies that can conjure the peril. (To be continued). PERSONAL AND SOCIAL SPORT AND PLAY. SALVAGE OF “FOYLE” PROBABLE. ( From oui Correspondent. ) Suez, Friday, The S.S. “Foyle” is now slightly makiDg water in No. 2 hold, and about 70 tons of rice ias been thrown overboard. Owing to the fine weather, disoharge is continuing satisfactorily, and up to the 24th inst., over 800 tons of dry rioe, and 500 tons of damaged rice, haul been discharged into lighters and landed at Perim. It is now expected that the “Foyle” will be shortly refloated if the weather continues favorable. The divers report that tittle damage is visible but fear it is considerable underneath the forepeak. THE MISSING SUEZ TUG. “TROTTER EGYPTIEN.” J The following is the programme of the fourth day’s raoing at the Hippodrome, Round Point, whioh takes place on the 22nd inst:— Prix de Hadra.—P.T. 700 (400 200 100). Pourchevaux amblenrs (Rahouan) attelAs on months. Epreuve unique—4 tours de piste 2364 metres—Entree P.T. 50. Entree P.T. 500—(Cette course auia lieu s’il y a an moins 6 engagements). Prix de la Promenade.—P.T. 300 de Sweep- stakes. Pour chevaux de la m®me dearie attelei en paire A des voitnres amt'ricaines A quatre rones eaontchontdes. Pour ohevaux de tons pays. Seront exolus lea trotteurs de course. Le.ler reoevra an objet d’art et le 65% sur les entries. Le 2me le 35%— Epreuve unique.—Distance 4 tours de piste 2364 mitres. Grand Handicap International. — P.T. 5.000 (3.000 1.000 700 300) En 2 Ipreuves— Pour tons chcvaux de Ire, 2me, 3me, 4rro olasse avec rendementi de distance suivant la vitesse cpnstatle en Egypte. Les ohevanx qui n’ont pas de vitesse constatle partiront scratch. Distance 3 tours de piste 1.780 m. minimum. Entile P.T. 300. Conditions G£n£rales.—Les courses sont soumises aux rlglements du Trotter Egyptian. Les inscriptions seront oloeea le 15 juillet A 4h. p.m., et devront Stre ad resales avec le montant des entiles an Seorltaire du Trotter Egyptian, Mr. O. della Marra, Rond-Point, ex Vllodrome, Alexandria KH EDI VIAL SPORTING CLUB ( From our Correspondent. ) Suez, Friday. The lighters laden with rioe belonging to the German steamer “Helene Riokmera” have been seen lying at anohor 20 miles south of Ras Gharib lighthouses, but nothing has been heard of the tug. Strong northerly winds prevail and a heavy sea is running in the Sum Gulf, so it is expected that the tog ha# taken shelter. The Regent, H.E. Mustapha Pasha Fehmy, is leading for Europe to-day by the Austrian Lloyd steamer. Scander Pasha andria yesterday. Fehmy arrived at Alex* Yacoub Pasha Artin and Abdallah Bey Sfer have returned to Cairo from Alexandria. Coles Pasha, with Mis. Coles and the Misses Coles, left Cairo for Port Said yesterday to join the Bibby boat. Harvey Pasha arrived to-day from Cairo. We regret to report the death, whioh ooouri red on the 19th nit, in the Bahr el Ghazal Pro- vince, of Kaimakam H. L. H. Fell Bey, R.N., Senior Inspector of the provinoe. The deceased officer resigned from active service in the Royal Navy with the rank of lieutenant, his commis- sion being restored nnder the provisions of the Order in Council of May 13, 1901. He was universally regarded as an officer of great pro- mise ; his work in the Bahr el Ghazal had been iconspicuously good, and his personal qualities endeared him to his comrades in the Sudan service. Fell Bey Was about to relieve Kaima- kam Drury Bey, R.N., AtSaahjjc ( FIRST WINTER MEETING. December 20th and 22nd 4905 ). COUNTRY BRED STAKES. Value LE. 100. Scale of Weights. 8 yean. 4 yean. 5 and over, iztClass C.B’s... 10.7 11. 8 11.10 2nd „ „ ... 9.8 9.18 10.10 Anbe... 7,0 ll. 8 9.18 J.10 11.10 10.10 8. 7 The Rev. F.'^B. N. Norman-Lee, S.O.F., and Mn. Norman-Lee are leaving on the 4th inst by the P. & 0. “Egypt” for England. Mr. and Mn. Norman-Lee take tins opportunity of thanking their numerous friends for their kind enquiries and sympathy daring Mrs. Nonnan* Lee’s severe illness. Mr. Noiman-I^e will be away for four months and during that time his duties at Alexandria will be performed by the Rev. Arthur H. Manning, acting chaplain to the Forces, who is staying at the Miramare Hotel, Ramleb. A cable from London states that Baron de Kusel Bey, manager of the Egyptian Tnut and Investment, Limited, has left for Egypt viA Brindisi, and iB due at Alexandria on Wednesday next Dr. Warpoek, medical superintendent of Ab- bassieh Asylum, left Egypt yestwday for England on three months’ leave of abeence. Mr. S. G. Violara left Alexandria to-day for a short holiday in Oieeoe.
